comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: Probably: Lieutenant William Harold Brett. The Worcestershire Regiment. discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/SearchUI/details/C10565... Also mentioned in the London Gazette, 5 August 1919, p. 10060: "Worc. R. [...] Temp. Lt. W. H. Brett relinquishes his commission on completion of service, 16 Apr. 1919, and retains the rank of Lt."

comment.author: 13706945@N00
comment._content: There are also a couple of mentions on some pages seemingly made available by the BBC’s Who Do You Think You Are? magazine. From the format and file paths, I think that they are taken from something like the Army List of 1916 and 1917. They both say that he achieved seniority as a 2nd Lieutenant on the 3rd April 1915, the second one adds that he was/is employed by the Ministry of Munitions: *Brett, W.H. (empld. Min. of Munitions), 3 Apr. 15 [the star means that the rank is temporary] Column 1172 (PDF): cdn.bbcmagazinesbristol.com/bbcwhodoyouthinkyouare/bonus_... Column 1172a (PDF): cdn.bbcmagazinesbristol.com/bbcwhodoyouthinkyouare/bonus_...

comment.author: 25889396@N02
comment._content: These may then be another W H Brett... 12242 Sapper W H Brett with RE, awarded DCM London Gazette 23 June 1915 Also a Wisden reference as follows SAPPER BRETT, who died of wounds in June, had the reputation of being the best wicket-keeper in the Metropolitan Police Force. He gained the D.C.M.
